title: Recombinant protein expression and purification of codon-optimized  Pfu-Sso7d

protocol.title: Recombinant protein expression and purification of codon-optimized  Pfu-Sso7d
protocol.title_html: Recombinant protein expression and purification of codon-optimized  Pfu-Sso7d

source.description:
Transform
of plasmid containing codon-optimized into E. coli C41 competent cells using either heat shock or electroporation.

Spread transformed cells in LB Agar plates supplemented with
Kan. Grow plate overnight at

Select a single colony from the LB agar plate to prepare a preinoculum in
LB media supplemented with
Kan. Grow overnight at

Use the full volume of the preinoculum to inoculate
of LB (or TB) media supplemented with
Kan (1% inoculation). Grow at
until reaching an optical density at 600 nm (OD600) = 0.8

Upon reaching OD600 = 0.8, add IPTG to a final concentration of
and incubate overnight at

Centrifuge the cell culture
.Then, resuspend the cell pellet in
of Buffer A freshly supplemented with
PMSF and
lysozyme.
Incubate the resuspended cells at

Sonicate on ice for
using cycles of
ON and
OFF at 40% amplitude (Qsonica Q125, 125W).

On an ultracentrifugation tube, Incubate the unclarified lysate at
for
to precipitate most of E. coli proteins, and then place on ice for
. Centrifuge
and collect the supernatant. You might want to collect a small sample for SDS-PAGE afterwards.

On a 1 mL HisTrap column preequilibrated with 10 column volumes (c.v.) (here, 10 mL) of Buffer A, load the supernant.
Wash with 10-20 c.v. of Buffer A.
Then, elute with 5 c.v. of Buffer B, collecting the eluted fractions every
in 1.5 ml tubes.

To quickly pool the fractions containing the protein of interest, prepare a 96-well plate or 1.5 mL tubes with
of Bradford reagent and
of distilled water. Then, add
of each protein fraction and compare against a blank reference sample corresponding to
of Buffer B. You can determine your protein-containing fractions either by absorbance at 595 nm on a plate reader or visually by comparing the blue coloration of each fraction against the blank reference. Pool your fractions and collect a
sample for SDS-PAGE

source.title: DAY 4B – Second purification and buffer exchange by Heparin

source.description:
This method was preferred over protein dyalisis or Amicon protein concentration to avoid using large buffer volumes and proteins crashing out of the solution.

Dilute the pooled fractions 3X in 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, such that the final concentration of NaCl is 100 mM.

source.title: DAY 4B – Second purification and buffer exchange by Heparin

source.description:
Next, load the diluted sample onto a 1 ml HiTrap Heparin column previously equilibrated with 10 c.v. (here, 10 mL) of Buffer HA.
Then, elute the protein using a 10 c.v. linear gradient against Buffer HB, collecting the eluted fractions every
in 1.5 mL tubes. The protein will elute at high concentrations between 300 and 600 mM NaCl

This linear gradient can be achieved by connecting two containers, one with 5 c.v. Buffer HA and the other with 5 c.v. Buffer HB, with a syphon or a tube, and withdrawing solution from Buffer HA container to the column using a cheap peristaltic pump or by gravity.

source.title: DAY 4B – Second purification and buffer exchange by Heparin

source.description:
Again, determine your protein-containing fractions using the Bradford assay. Pool your fractions and determine its protein concentration using the same method and collect a
sample for SDS-PAGE.

source.title: DAY 4B – Second purification and buffer exchange by Heparin

source.description:
For storage, supplement your pooled fraction with
Nonidet P-40 and
EDTA. Then, dilute the sample by adding glycerol up to
to reach final storage conditions: 25 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0, ~250 mM NaCl, 0.1 mM EDTA, 0.1% Nonidet P-40, 50% glycerol.

source.title: DAY 4B – Second purification and buffer exchange by Heparin

source.description:
Generate
aliquots of the enzyme and store it at
until required. Usual final protein concentrations for storage are between
and

description:
This protocol has been optimized for the recombinant expression of a codon-optizimed Pfu-Sso7d DNA polymerase. This is a fusion protein composed of the Pfu enzyme from Pyrococcus furiosus for DNA amplification by PCR fused to a small 7 kDa protein from Sulfobulus solfataricus that binds to double-stranded DNA without any preference for specific sequences, thus enhancing polymerization processivity without affecting the catalytic activity or thermal stability of the enzyme.

The goal of this protocol was to eliminate the use of large volumes for dyalisis and potential issues with the protein crashing out of the solution due to the use of concentrators for buffer exchange of this enzyme into storage conditions. We also eliminated the use of DTT, which is often found in other similar protocols.

The sequence plasmid encoding the codon-optimized Pfu-Sso7d enzyme used here can be found at https://benchling.com/s/seq-2TcUPjO2uMbDG5ufTQN4
materials_text:
MATERIALS










Buffer A, pH 8.0
NaPO4, pH 8.0
dextrose
NaCl
EDTA
Nonidet P-40
Imidazole, pH 8.0

Buffer B, pH 8.0
NaPO4, pH 8.0
dextrose
NaCl
EDTA
Nonidet P-40
Imidazole, pH 8.0

Buffer C , pH 8.0
NaPO4, pH 8.0
dextrose
NaCl
EDTA
Nonidet P-40
Imidazole, pH 8.0

Buffer HA, pH 8.0
Tris-HCl, pH 8.0
NaCl
Nonidet P-40

Buffer HB, pH 8.0
Tris-HCl, pH 8.0
NaCl
Nonidet P-40
